text: In 2007, federal prosecutors prepared a 32-count draft indictment describing Epstein as an extremely high flight risk and a continued danger to the community.
source: DOJ Released Files, 2007 Draft Indictment — reported by NYT, AP
context: The indictment was never filed. Instead, U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta signed off on a plea deal.

text: Ghislaine Maxwell was mentioned 13,169 times across the released Epstein files, making her one of the most frequently referenced individuals.
source: DOJ Epstein Files Release, January 2026 — reported by BBC, CNN
context: Maxwell was convicted in 2021 of sex trafficking and is currently serving a 20-year sentence.

text: Epstein's assistant Lesley Groff appeared 157,613 times in the released documents, the highest mention count of any individual in the files.
source: DOJ Epstein Files, February 2026 analysis — reported by multiple outlets
context: Groff served as Epstein's executive assistant for decades and was identified as an alleged co-conspirator.

text: Flight logs showed Epstein's private planes made over 1,700 documented flights between November 1995 and August 2013.
source: Unsealed flight manifests, Giuffre v. Maxwell — reported by Business Insider
context: The logs were unsealed during Virginia Giuffre's defamation case against Maxwell.

text: An FBI employee diagram showed Epstein's inner circle including Maxwell, lawyer Darren Indyke, and accountant Richard Kahn.
source: DOJ Released Files — reported by CNN, NYT
context: The undated diagram also listed French model agent Jean-Luc Brunel among Epstein's close associates.

text: Peter Mandelson allegedly sent market sensitive UK government information to Epstein, including Prime Minister Gordon Brown's secret pseudonym.
source: DOJ Epstein Files — reported by BBC, The Guardian, ITV News
context: Brown's pseudonym was reportedly 'John Pond' and his secure email address was also shared.

text: In 2008, Epstein accepted a plea deal in Florida and pleaded guilty to soliciting prostitution from someone under age 18.
source: Palm Beach County Court Records — reported by Miami Herald
context: The deal, overseen by U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, allowed Epstein to avoid federal charges.

text: French model agent Jean-Luc Brunel was mentioned 4,727 times in the files before dying by suicide in a Paris jail in 2022.
source: DOJ Epstein Files — reported by BBC, AP
context: Brunel faced rape charges in France and was under investigation for sex trafficking of minors.

text: The DOJ released 3 million pages on January 30, 2026, including 2,000 videos and 180,000 images from the investigation.
source: U.S. Department of Justice Press Release, January 30, 2026
context: The DOJ stated this would be the final release, claiming it met obligations under the Epstein Files Transparency Act.

text: FBI agents identified over 35 underage girls with similar stories of abuse at Epstein's Palm Beach mansion during their investigation.
source: FBI Investigation Records — reported by Miami Herald, Vox
context: The investigation began in 2005 after a woman reported her 14-year-old stepdaughter was taken to the property.

text: An employee at Epstein's Florida estate told the FBI he was instructed to fan hundred-dollar bills on a table near Epstein's bed.
source: FBI Interview Notes, DOJ Release — reported by AP
context: The same employee described disposing of used condoms and placing a gun between Epstein's mattresses.

text: Al Seckel emailed Epstein in 2010 about replacing his mugshot on Wikipedia and removing the term sex offender from his article.
source: DOJ Epstein Files, Email Records — reported by multiple outlets
context: This was part of Epstein's efforts to rebuild his public image after being released from jail in July 2009.

text: Virginia Giuffre filed a defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell that led to the unsealing of thousands of court documents.
source: Giuffre v. Maxwell, U.S. District Court SDNY
context: The lawsuit resulted in multiple rounds of document releases starting in 2019 and continuing through 2024.

text: A United Nations panel stated the Epstein files revealed a global criminal enterprise that could meet the threshold of crimes against humanity.
source: UN Human Rights Council Statement, February 2026 — reported by Reuters, BBC
context: The panel of independent experts was appointed by the UN Human Rights Council.

text: Epstein owned a private island called Little Saint James in the U.S. Virgin Islands where much of the alleged abuse took place.
source: Property records, U.S. Virgin Islands — widely reported
context: The island was colloquially known as 'Pedophile Island' and was a key location in the investigation.

text: The Epstein Files Transparency Act was passed by the House, unanimously approved by the Senate, and signed by President Trump in November 2025.
source: U.S. Congress Records — reported by NBC, AP
context: Trump had floated the idea of releasing the files during his 2024 presidential campaign.

text: Former Norwegian prime minister Thorbjorn Jagland was charged with aggravated corruption due to his ties to Epstein revealed in the files.
source: DOJ Epstein Files — reported by international media, February 2026
context: Jagland was one of three people who had criminal investigations launched after the files were released.

text: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was arrested on February 19, 2026, following revelations in the released Epstein documents about his connections.
source: DOJ Epstein Files — reported by BBC, The Guardian, NYT
context: Andrew had previously strenuously denied any wrongdoing related to Epstein.

text: Journalist Julie Brown published an investigative series about Epstein's abuse and plea deal in the Miami Herald in 2018.
source: Miami Herald, 'Perversion of Justice' series
context: Brown's reporting prompted a fresh investigation by New York federal prosecutors that led to Epstein's 2019 arrest.

text: In 1996, Maria Farmer reported to the FBI that Epstein had stolen naked photos of her underage siblings, but no investigation was conducted.
source: FBI Records — reported by NYT, Miami Herald
context: This was one of the earliest known reports about Epstein's criminal behavior.

text: Les Wexner, the billionaire founder of L Brands, employed Epstein as a money manager and claimed he severed ties in 2007.
source: DOJ Files, Business Records — reported by NYT, WSJ
context: Wexner granted Epstein sweeping power over his finances and gave him a Manhattan townhouse.

text: An 86-page memo titled Investigation into Potential Co-Conspirators was sent to US Attorney Geoffrey Berman on December 19, 2019.
source: DOJ Released Files, SDNY Prosecution Memo — reported by Miami Herald
context: The memo contained statements from 24 women who reported being abused as minors and 14 as adults.

text: Epstein's Gulfstream jet with tail number N908JE was the primary aircraft used in flights documented in the logs.
source: FAA Records, Flight Manifests — reported by Business Insider
context: The plane was commonly referred to as the 'Lolita Express' in media coverage.

text: Epstein died in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan on August 10, 2019, in what was ruled a suicide.
source: NYC Medical Examiner Report — widely reported
context: His death sparked widespread conspiracy theories and criticism of the federal prison system.

text: The Jmail archive has catalogued over 1.4 million files and 2.4 million pages from the DOJ release and House Oversight Committee.
source: Jmail Archive Statistics, February 2026
context: Jmail is a browser-based archive dedicated to making the Epstein files searchable and accessible.

text: Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted in December 2021 of sex trafficking and conspiracy and sentenced to 20 years in federal prison.
source: U.S. v. Maxwell, SDNY — widely reported
context: Maxwell was found guilty on five of six counts after a month-long trial in Manhattan.

text: Common flight routes included Teterboro to Palm Beach and Palm Beach to Saint Thomas with different passengers on each leg.
source: Flight Manifests, Giuffre v. Maxwell — reported by Business Insider
context: Passengers would join or depart at different stops, complicating efforts to track who visited the island.

text: Johanna Sjoberg gave a 2016 deposition mentioning politicians and public figures she encountered at Epstein's properties.
source: Giuffre v. Maxwell Court Documents, 2024 Unsealing — reported by TIME
context: Sjoberg was one of Epstein's victims who provided testimony in the Maxwell defamation lawsuit.

text: In her deposition, Maxwell appeared to confirm that Andrew visited Epstein's island in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
source: Giuffre v. Maxwell Deposition Transcripts — reported by The Guardian
context: Andrew has denied visiting the island, contradicting multiple witness accounts.

text: After Epstein's 2019 arrest, FBI agents discussed serving grand jury summonses to Maxwell and nine other alleged co-conspirators.
source: FBI Email Records, DOJ Release — reported by Daily Mail
context: Three were located and served in Florida, with others found in Boston, NYC, and Connecticut.

text: Donald Trump and Melania Trump were referenced more than 38,000 times across the released Epstein files collection.
source: DOJ Epstein Files Analysis, February 2026
context: The frequency of mentions reflects the volume of documents, not allegations of wrongdoing.

text: Epstein's estate is managed by lawyer Darren Indyke and accountant Richard Kahn, who controlled over 300 gigabytes of data.
source: DOJ Epstein Files, Estate Records — reported by ABC News
context: The estate data was stored in the FBI's Sentinel case management system.

text: Alexander Acosta served as U.S. Attorney in Florida and approved the controversial non-prosecution agreement with Epstein in 2008.
source: DOJ Records, Office of Professional Responsibility — reported by Miami Herald
context: Acosta later served as Secretary of Labor under Trump but resigned in 2019 amid renewed scrutiny.

text: Peter Listerman was described in Epstein's files as a model scout and matchmaker who served as both a subject and witness.
source: DOJ Released Files, FBI Diagram — reported by CNN
context: Listerman appeared in the FBI's diagram of Epstein's inner circle of associates.

text: The DOJ acknowledged that approximately 6 million pages might qualify as responsive documents under the Epstein Files Transparency Act.
source: DOJ Statement, January 2026 — reported by CNN, NBC
context: Critics argued the 3.5 million pages released were insufficient given the total estimated volume.

text: An Epstein employee told the FBI about delivering flowers to a student at Royal Palm Beach High School on Epstein's orders.
source: FBI Interview Notes, DOJ Release — reported by AP
context: The delivery was to commemorate the student's performance in a school play.

text: Epstein was first indicted in New York in July 2019 on charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy involving dozens of minors.
source: U.S. v. Epstein, SDNY Indictment — widely reported
context: The new charges came after journalist Julie Brown's reporting reignited public interest in the case.

text: Gordon Brown's secret pseudonym was revealed as John Pond in emails found within the released Epstein document collection.
source: DOJ Epstein Files, Email Records — reported by BBC, ITV News
context: The pseudonym and Brown's secure email were allegedly shared with Epstein by Peter Mandelson.

text: Victims and advocates criticized the Justice Department for heavy but inconsistent redactions of names throughout the released documents.
source: DOJ Release Response — reported by CNN, NYT
context: Five individuals on the FBI diagram had their names and photographs redacted by the DOJ.

text: The Epstein investigation included files from five primary sources covering the Florida and New York criminal cases.
source: DOJ Press Release, January 30, 2026
context: Sources included cases against Epstein, Maxwell, investigations into Epstein's death, and the OIG investigation.
